name: Aberavon
description: This forecast uses the same data as the Porthcawl one but reflects the slightly different wind requirements of the break.

name: Aberdeen - Beach
description: Covering all the Aberdeen area breaks based on a South West being offshore (adjust slightly for Nigg Bay)

name: Anglesey (Ynys MÃ´n)
description: Covering all south west facing breaks on the coast of Anglesey. Uses the same data as the Hells Mouth forecast.

name: Balevullin
description: Sits facing north west and is directly offshore in a south sast wind and picks up swell from the NW to SW. If the swell is north it gets completely blocked by the outer Hebrides and if too south then Ireland blocks it. Hollowest on low tide and works on all tides except high.

name: Ballybunion
description: Ballybunion - Beach

name: Banff - Beach
description: Covering all breaks in the Banff / MacDuff area.

name: Banna Beach
description: Typical beachbreak

name: Bantham
description: Bantham, Bigbury and Challaborough are the main focus of the South Devon scene and catch their share of swell. i\'i

name: Barmouth
description: Covering the region from Harlech, Llandanwg south to Barmouth.

name: Barrel Rock
description: Crazy barrel a bit shallow on the inside tho!!!

name: Beadnell Bay
description:
The Bay can accommodate swells upto 12-15ft in size. Usually you choose the Bay due to its favorable wind directions and protected swell. The North end of the Bay needs a big (5ft+) south/south-easterly swell to work well. The middle of the Bay can produce excellent waves through most swell directions and sizes. The far south of the Bay is more open and holds big open northerly swells.

The Carrs reef in the midde of the Bay produces a left and a right that can hold swell upto 10ft easily and can result in quality 150 yard rides.

Always try and get the central to north end of the Bay on the pushing or high tide, the banks are better an the swell gets into the beach over the reefs more easily.

The Carrs reefs need a high tide to work and soon become exposed about an hour and a half after high.

name: Benone Strand
description: Benone Strand is a beautiful 7 mile stretch of beach which runs from the mouth of the Lough Foyle to the famous Musseneden Temple at Downhill. During big storms the west end of the beach can be very sheltered. There are multiple peaks running down the entire beach with a wave for every type of surfer.

name: Bertra Beach (Murrisk)
description: Next to Murrisk, beach break, offshore on an easterly wind

name: Birling Gap
description: Just a chance of some groundswell reaching Birling gap. Often surfed on SW wind swells.

name: Birsay Bay
description: Covering breaks in the bay area.

name: Blackpool South
description: South Pier and Starr Gate. Breaks best towards high tide on a spring tide. Faces slightly north of due west. Beach break.

name: Borth / Ynyslas
description: Covering all breaks in the Aberdovey bay area and south to Aberystwyth.

name: Bournemouth
description: Popular (and crowded) south coast breaks getting an irregular supply of groundswell. The forecast includes all the beaches from Bournemouth through Boscombe to Southbourne.

name: Bracklesham Bay
description: Long stretch of beach. Most people surf in front of the car park situated right on the seafront.

name: Brighton - West Pier
description: Brighton, Worthing and Hove really are almost the last chance up the Channel to pick up a bit of groundswell. Can get good and will always be contested when it is.

name: Brimms Ness - The Point
description: Catching a great deal more west swell than Thurso the forecast might be similar but the actual wave considerably different.

name: Broadstairs - Viking Bay
description: Viking Bay is the main bay in the picturesque and quintessential British seaside town of Broadstairs. It is a great alternative to the nearby beach of Joss Bay, which can be overcrowded. It has a cleaner more sheltered and mellower wave at low tide from the end of the harbour jetty and is ideally suited to longboarders, the inside of the bay is excellent for beginners. It works on all stages of tide, but best a couple hours either side of low, tends to have a closing out beach break at high tide.North sea swell from NW through to E is best, but can have a wave on a strong S-SW channel swell. East winds are on shore. There are lifeguards on beach in summer, and there is a surf school and hire centre.

name: Bu Sands
description: Good for most East facing breaks in the Orkneys

name: Bude - Crooklets
description: Covering the surrounding area including Widemouth Bay.

name: Bundoran - The Peak
description: This forecast covers a range of breaks including Bundoran and beaches to the north and south (Rossnowlagh, Tullan, Streedagh Strand).

name: Bunmahon
Camber sands
description: One of the best (old school with a lot of surf history) sandy/flat storm beach\'s in Kent, that picks up any good swell pushing up the English channel that also effect Wittering or Brighton. breaks halfway up to high tide then half way down. with good shouldering waves that break\'s slowly over many sand bars (plus the one down by the river mouth which can be good if wind is on shore) all along this section and is especially good for stand up paddle boarding. \r\n\r\nSurf is best 2 to 3 hrs before high tide, then the first 2 to 3 hours after high tide. Best locations; if windy harbour wall end, furthest walk to the west of the beach, towards Rye Harbour river approach. If less windy or better still off-shore, then Jury\'s Gap beach, which is to the east end of Camber Sands Bay, Stony Beach (close to kitesurf centre). Sandettie wave buoy is a relevant buoy for this spot.

name: Carrowniskey
description: One of the most consistent beaches in Ireland

name: Cayton Bay - Pumphouse
description: Popular but fickle bay, good quality right and lefts.

name: Challaborough
description: Challaborough along with Bantham and Bigbury are the main focus of the South Devon scene.

name: Clogherhead
description: Beach and reef setups that work on all easterly swells.

name: Coldingham Bay
description: Good for spots around the Scottish border.

name: Constantine
description: Also covering Treyarnon

name: Corblets Bay
description: Situated at the northern end of the island has several small beaches, and Corblets is a sheltered, North facing horseshoe bay, which picks up swell on big days.

name: Cromer
description: Both breaks recieve more swell than perhaps expected and are the hub of the East Anglian scene. This forecast is good for the surrounding coast.

name: Croyde Beach
description: Covering all the main popular North Devon beaches.

name: Culdaff
description: Beach break.

name: drivers
description: hollow left, best at mid tide

name: Dublin Area
description:
<b>Important</b><br/>
Note that the swell data for this location is some way south in St Georges channel and will miss local wind swells. If you check the swell direction you'll see that it is almost always heading away from the Dublin area beaches. As such this forecast is useful only for local winds and occasional strong easterly wind swells. We will be including new nearshore data here soon which will hugely improve the forecast.

name: Dunfanaghy
description: Good indicator spot

name: East Wittering
description: East and West Weittering are about the last spot before Brighton to get any kind of Channel groundswell.

name: Elly Bay West
description: Classic beachbreak, rights and lefts. Works best from low to mid tide, light onshore winds on mid sized Westerly or North Westerly swell.

name: Eoropie
description: Covering breaks in the area.

name: Exmouth
description: This forecast will give local winds but channel swell data. Be aware that there may be west or south west swell coming up the channel but it won't reach here. You need to look out for east or south swells for this area (hence the ratings will not always be correct).

name: Falmouth
description: Covering the bay area

name: Filey
description: Covering the bay area.

name: Fisk Helliar
description: Covering all North facing breaks.

name: Folkestone
description: Beach break that only works in the height of winter on a strong SW swell. When it is working it works best for consistent sets on a low-mid tide.

name: Fraserburgh
description:
Covering all breaks in the area.<p/>

<tt>"The beach is shaped like a large hoseshoe and meaning the SE end is slean on SE wind and the North end can handle winds from SW right round to North especially at high tide when there is a lot of shelter from the prom and caravan site especially from Wto NNW and a lesser extent N wind."</tt>Broch Local

name: Freshwater West
description:
Long, consistent beach with reef options.<p/>

We've been asked a number of times why our reports here aren't always the same as the Pembroke buoy. <a href="/content/surf-forecasting.php?article=17">Here is the complete explanation.</a>

name: Garretstown
description: Cork beachbreak

name: Glenbrittle
description: Large open beach break. SW facing. Car park and campsite on beach.

name: Gorleston
description: This forecast covers all spots in the Great Yarmouth area.

name: Great Yarmouth
description: Doesn\'t get big very often.

name: Greve de Lecq - Jersey
description:
Shore/beach break, breaks on the shore at mid-high only surfable low tide
gives fast hollow barrels good for bodyboarders near the pier and surfers nearer the rocks. Works on big north-westerly swell and a strong southerly wind.

name: Gwithian
description: Covers all the breaks in the St Ives area but based on the SE Winds required for Godrevy (Adjust for Carbis Bay etc.)

name: Harlyn
description: Indicator for north facing Cornish beaches\\\\\\\\r\\\\\\\\n

name: Hells Mouth (Porth Neigwl)
Highcliffe
description: Relatively fun sandbars off shingle beaches broken up by rock groynes. Generally a few different bars provide mostly average, pushy waves, but occasionally a good bank settles down and provides the faithfuls with some fun, punchy waves. Same swells as Bournemouth area, although picks up a bit more on good days, same winds.

name: Hornsea
description: Beach Break. Works on all states of tide. Generally best from mid to high tide.

name: Inch Reefs
description: Covering both Reef and strand and useful for a general swell and wind forecast for the entire Dingle peninsula.

name: Islay (Machir Bay)
description: Covering all west facing spots including Saligo Bay, Machir Bay, Lossit Bay and Laggan Bay

name: Isle of Wight - Compton
description: Covering all south west facing beaches from Freshwater and Compton bay down the coast to St Catherines point.

name: Jersey
description:
Covering all west facing breaks including Watersplash. For other spots adjust the wind accordingly.<p/>

Check out the <a href="http://www.surfingjersey.net/">Jersey Surf Club</a> or <a href="http://www.watersplashjersey.com/"> www.watersplashjersey.com</a> for local news and events.

name: Joss Bay
description: Joss bay is amongst the very few Kent spots to get any kind of groundswell - in this case large North Sea swells make it down to the coast on occasion.

name: Lackan Bay / Kilcummin
description: We don\'t have any details about Lackan Bay at the moment.

name: Lahinch - Cornish Left
description: This forecast covers Lahinch south to Donegal point.

name: Langland Bay
description: Covering Langland Bay, Caswell bay and other local beaches this forecast is based on the Northerly offshores ideal at Langland. Again using the same swell data as Aberavon and Porthcawl forecasts.

name: Llangennith
description: Covering the long beach from Broughton Bay down through Llangennith beach to Rhossili Bay. Again using the same swell data as all the Gower forecasts adjusted for the required Easterly winds.

name: Llangrannog
description: Beachbreak

name: Lowestoft
description: Covering the Lowestoft area including north to Great Yarmouth

name: Lunan Bay
description: This forecast is for Dundee area breaks.

name: Lusty Glaze
description: Solid beachbreak just north of Newquay\\\'s main town beaches. Best on the low tide push.

name: Lyme Regis
description: Covering breaks in the area - needs large south swells or south west wind swells to work. Our rating will be based on all channel swells so may be optimistic for this area - adjust accordingly.

name: Lynmouth
description: Long left hand point break, boulder bottomed, breaks on moderate to large westerly swell and southerly winds. One of the best quality pointbreaks in the country. Super crowded when ever it\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\'s working, with a high level of surfer. Not for the fainthearted.

name: Machrihanish
Mangersta
description: Good for Mangersta and also Valtos.

name: Manorbier
description:
The break is offshore on a NEasterly although anything from N-SSE is good. At high to mid tide a right hander breaks off a reef at the N end of the bay, at low tide waves break on sand. 

On a typical SW swell Manorbier is about half the size of Fresh but a more northerly swell means the difference is often greater, or less for a southerly swell. 

Manorbier is a consistent and well-known break surfed regularly throughout the year.

name: Marwick
description: Well known and widely surfed fast right hand reef break, the jewel in the crown of surfing spots in Orkney

name: Newgale
description: Covering all the breaks in the St. Brides Bay area.

name: Newquay - Fistral North
description: Considered by many the epicenter of the UK scene Fistral hosts most of the major UK comps and is both a quality wave and consistently crowded. This surf forecast covers all the main beaches of the region including Town beaches, Porth Beach, the Cribber and Watergate bay.

name: Newquay - Towan / Great Western
description: Covering the town\\\\\\\'s north facing beaches (Tolcarne, Great Western and Towan) \\\\r\\\\n

name: North Malin
description: This forecast assumes that a South wind is offshore - but with beaches facing about 180ÃÂ° you should be able to find some offshore here. Just adjust the forecast to compensate.

name: Paignton
description: Beachbreak which rarely gets surf during the summer season and works on all easterly swells.

name: Pease Bay
description: This forecast covers all spots in this area.

name: Pentewan
description: We don't have any details about Pentewan at the moment.

name: Perranporth (Droskyn)
description: Covering the Perranporth/ Penhale sands area

name: Peterhead (Sandford Bay)
description: Covering the area from Inverallochy, St. Combs and south to Sandford.

name: Plemont Bay - Jersey
description:
Great little beach break, only surfable mid-low tide 
works on a 3ft+ west/northerly swell with a light southerly wind. Rocks are a hazard.

name: Polzeath
description: A popular summer break with slow breaking rights and lefts. \\r\\n

name: Poppit Sands
description: Beach break with rivermouth peaks.

name: Port Bharrapol (Tiree)
description: Covering all breaks on the Island but assuming a south east wind is offshore - adjust for other spots.

name: Porthcawl - Coney Beach
description: Covering Rest bay and beaches south of Porthcawl this forecast is based on the easterly offshores needed at Rest Bay.

name: Porthleven
description: Shallow barrelling a-frame over reef. Crowded, competitive and only suitable for advanced surfers.

name: Porthtowan
description: Covering the area from Holywell Bay, Penhale, throught Droskyn Beach and St Agnes down through Porthtowan to Portreath. Most of these breaks work in a similar wind and swell.

name: Portrush
description: Covering all breaks in the Portrush area, rating adjusted assuming South East winds are offshore (for other breaks adjust accordingly).

name: Praa Sands
description: Covering all spots between Penzance and the Lizard.

name: Putsborough
description: The southern end of Woolacombe beach offering protection in a south westerly wind\r\n

name: S*** Pipe
description: Hollow right hander, breaks best at low.

name: Saltburn Beach
description: Covering the area from Hartlepool beaches in the north to Skinningrove in the south. Assuming a south westerly is offshore (adjust for other spots)

name: Sandymouth
description: Picks up a little more swell than Bude itself and works from low through mid tide.

name: Scarasta
description: Good for any NE facing Harris breaks.

name: Scarborough - North Bay
description: Scarborough North

name: Scarborough - South Bay
description: South Bay

name: Sennen
description: As far west as you can get in England and picking up most of the Atlantic swell available.

name: Sidmouth (Lyme Bay)
description: This forecast will give local winds but channel swell data. Be aware that there may be west or south west swell coming up the channel but it probably won\\\'t reach here. You need to look out for east or south swells for this area (hence the ratings will not always be correct).

name: Sinclairs Bay - Beach
description: Covering spots from Skirza / Freswick bay south.

name: Skail Bay Right
description: Covering the bay breaks and north to the reefs in the Marwick area.

name: Skegness
description: Covering all east facing beaches in the area.

name: Southwold
description: Needs a heavy dose of swell to show a wave.

name: St Andrews East
description: This forecast covers all breaks in the St. Andrews area.

name: St Bees
description: Beach break, Southerly, South westerly, North Westerly swells. Need further input for best conditions, tide state. Best after a big blow is dying off. Parking, cafe,  For the Cumbrian coast perhaps the most likely to have decent waves,

name: St Brelades - Jersey
description: Nice beachbreak, works mid to high and best on the incoming tide. Works great with a large south/west swell and a stiff northerly breeze.

name: Staffin Bay
description: Beach break with shifting peaks. Works best on mid-low tide and Northerly swell. Footpath sign from main road to car park at Brogaig (473 684) then 400m path to beach.

name: Strandhill
description: This forecast covers breaks from Strandhill through west to Easkey (and surrounding area).

name: Sunderland
description: Covering Sunderlands beaches and north to Whitburn.

name: Surf Snowdonia
description: Surf Snowdonia is the world's first commercial wave pool using wave garden technology. With consistent waves year round it's never flat, despite our forecast taking data from the nearest stretch of coast at the moment!

name: Sutton on Sea
description: With a long E / ENE facing coastline this forecast should be good for most of the Lincolnshire coast north to the Humber and south to the Skegness forecast.

name: Talisker Bay
description: West facing beach break, working best with a SW swell. Left and right peaks. Car park (326 306) then 1km path to beach.

name: Teignmouth
description: Bear in mind that the swell data is taken a little way offshore and will show some west and southwest swell which is very unlikely to show itself here - keep an eye out for easterly swells coming down the channel

name: Tenby South Beach
description: Covering Tenby through to Freshwater East and assuming a west wind is offshore. Adjust for Manorbier winds (where NE is offshore).

name: The edge
description: right hander, best at low

name: The Point
description: right an left peak, high tide break

name: Thurso East
description: Covering Thurso east and Dunnet bay breaks. Swell and winds will be the same for NE facing breaks in the area - adjust the rating accordingly.

name: Tidemills
description: Works best two hours before or the two hours after low tide.

name: Torbay
description: We don't have any details about Torbay at the moment.

name: Tramore - Strand
description: Covering all breaks around the Tramore area and assuming that a North wind is offshore (just allow for this is surfing breaks at a different angle)

name: Trebarwith strand
description: Trebarwith strand is approximately 2 and a half miles south of Tintagel and can be reached on foot along the coast path. The beach is at the bottom of a deep valley. the surf is usually best at low tide to avoid rocks.

name: Vazon Bay - Beach - Guernsey
description: Covering all North West facing spots on the Island based on Vazon Bay. Swell and wind data will be the same for other spots, just adjust the star rating for breaks facing different directions

name: Watergate Bay
description: A popular contest site and more than just an overspill for Newquay.

name: Wembury
description: Wembury is the main focus of the Plymouth scene, catching the same swell as Bantham.

name: West Wittering
description: Giant car park but can be pricey in the summer. Quite a few peaks along this part of the beach with quality very much depending upon the quality of the sand.

name: Whitby
description: Covering a number of breaks and beaches in the area.

name: Whitsand Bay
description: The main local beaches for Plymouth based surfers.

name: Widemouth Bay
description: Large beach south of Bude with two easy access car parks at the north and south. Good peaks are dotted up and down the length but watch out for rocks.

name: Withernsea
description: This forecast covers all beaches close for Hull surfers.

name: Woolacombe
description: Mellow, open beachbreak peaks working through the tide
